page.title: 05LIFEBOAT TODAY SWANAGE
page.content: The Swanage lifeboat was built in 1973/4 and went into service in 1974. She was named J. Reginald-Corah by the Duke of Kent in 1975. There is only one full-time lifeboat man and he launches the boat. A launch is possible in any weather but returning back to the lifeboat house is not so easy. If the sea is too rough the lifeboat has to go to Poole Harbour to seek shelter. Then if it is a low water they have to moor off the coast until it can be safely winched back up the slipway. Once the boat is back on dry land it has to be refuelled at once so that she is ready for action again. The lifeboat has also to be checked very frequently to ensure that she is always sea worthy. It is pushed half way down the slipway so the coxswain can inspect all round it.
